block.p: Nasdaq Plummets 3.2%; Other Gauges Are Mixed The Nasdaq composite index suffered its worst one-day point loss since late July, falling 113.07 points, or 3.2 percent, to 3,455.83.

Other market indexes were narrowly mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 19.61 points, or 0.2 percent, to 10,719.74. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dipped 9.77 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,426.46. [Page C12.]

Tighter Rules Urged for Rail Deals A government panel that regulates railroads proposed rules that would end a bias toward approving mergers and make applicants show that a combined railroad would enhance competition and function smoothly. [C2.]

Drug Maker to Pay $30 Million Fine American Home Products said that it had agreed to pay the federal government $30 million after regulators found that the company had repeatedly violated manufacturing regulations at two of its drug factories. [C18.]

Tale of a True Survivor in Russia Igor Panin says he has been doing stunts since before he was born, having survived a car crash when his mother was eight months pregnant. Some 37 years later, he is still doing stunts in films and elsewhere, and as the chairman of the Master Association of Stuntmen in Moscow, must often traverse the Russian bureaucracy. The Boss. [C9.]

Little Anxiety Over China Web Rules Chinese Internet entrepreneurs and their foreign backers expressed only mild concern about the potential effect of new rules that require all Internet companies to apply for licenses in the next two months. [C2.]

Policy on Genetic Food Is Upheld A federal judge has upheld the Food and Drug Administration's policy on genetically modified food, throwing out a lawsuit by biotechnology opponents that sought to require that such foods be labeled and tested for safety. [C18.]

U.S. Responds Early to Microsoft Trying to demonstrate that the appeal of the Microsoft verdict can be handled quickly, the Justice Department proposed a schedule for the filing of documents in the case two days earlier than scheduled. [C4.]
Higher Business Air Fares Forecast American Express predicted that business air fares would increase more than 5 percent next year. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. [C10.]
